text.p: These are the leading stories in the Sarajevo press on Wednesday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
- OSCE coordinator of international monitoring said on Tuesday that he would recommend certification for Bosnia's September 14 elections although they were neither fair nor free.

- The forensic team of the International Tribunal for war crimes for the former Yugoslavia, that has been working at a mass grave site near the eastern Bosnia village of Pilice, will soon leave, the U.N. said.
- Heavy rainfall over the last couple of days has caused floods in most of Bosnia and claimed one victim.

- The United States suspended arms deliveries to Bosnia's Moslem-Croat Federation because the two federal partners have failed to form a joint Ministry of Defense and a joint command for the Federal army.
- An explosive device was thrown into the garden of a local Croatian official in Bihac on Thursday.
- The United States Agency for International Development awarded a 900,000 German mark loan to the Sarajevo textile producer Alhos on Tuesday. The loan will create jobs for 70 employees.
